sen.j: 下馬（げば）は、貴人の前で、社寺の境内で、また城内に入る前に、敬意を表わすために、騎（の）っているウマから下りることである。
sen.e: "Geba" meant to dismount one's horse in order to salute in front of nobles, in the precincts of shrines and temples, or before entering into a castle.
"Geba" means to dismount one's horse in order to salute in front of nobles, in the precincts of shrines and temples, or before entering a castle.
sen.cmt: 「下馬」は広辞苑にも現在載っている単語なので、特に過去形にする必要はないと考え、meant → means に訂正しました。文法間違い：Entering into → entering に訂正しました。
sen.e: "Geba" means to dismount one's horse in order to salute in front of nobles, in the precincts of shrines and temples, or before entering a castle.

sen.j: 同じように輿車から降りる場合は、「下乗」という。
sen.e: In the same manner, getting out of a palanquin is called "gejo."

sen.j: 「法曹至要抄」には、三位以下の者が路上で親王に会えば下馬するのをはじめとして、位階に応じてそれぞれ下馬の令制を載せ、有位者でない場合も賤者、少者は貴人、老人に対して同様にすべきであった。
sen.e: According to "Hososhiyo-sho" (a legal book compiled by the Sakanoue clan between the end of the Heian Period and the early Kamakura Period), which described rules and regulations on dismounting a horse depending on his court rank based on the Ritsuryo Law system (an ancient administrative law system in Japan), a person of the third court rank or the lower had to dismount his horse when he met any imperial prince on the road, as well as any lower-ranked or younger person without Ikai (a court rank) had to follow the same manner toward the nobilities and aged persons.

sen.j: 令制に背くと笞罪に処せられたという。
sen.e: If such rules and regulations were not observed, the offenders are said to have been punished with whippings.

sen.j: 「貞丈雑記」には、「輿にめしたる人に行あひ、又は人の犬追物、笠懸、やぶさめ、大的、小的など射らるる場所近き辺を通るとき、又は野山にて幕などうち遊興せらるるあたりを通るとき、または神社仏寺の前を通るとき、また三職などの門前を通るとき、または川狩鷹狩など人のするところを通るとき、また鷹すゑたる人鵜つかひに行あひたるとき、いづれも我知らぬ人なりとも、必ず下馬して通る也」とあり、武家時代を通じて、礼儀として厳存した。
sen.e: However, this custom of dismounting a horse had surely existed as a courtesy during Buke-jidai (the feudal period), as described in "Teijo-zakki" (a book on ancient courtly traditions and etiquettes, written by Sadatake Ise in the Edo Period) that a person had to dismount his horse without fail when he encountered with any person on a palanquin, or when he passed by a place where inuoimono (dog-hunting event, a skill of an archery), kasagake (archery competion on horseback), yabusame (the art of arrow shooting on horseback), and other arrow shooing competitions with omato and komato (big and small sized shooing targets) were being played, or when he went around a shrouded place for pleasure in hills and fields, or when he passed in front of shrines and temples, or when he passed in front of the gates of Sanshoku (three important offices), or when he passed through a place where people were enjoying river fishing or falconry and met with "Takasuetaru Hitou-tsukai" (a cormorant fisher or an astringer), in each case no matter whom he met with were strangers or not.
sen.cmt: 「鷹すえたる人鵜つかひ」の意味不明。一応推測で、「鵜匠または鷹匠」と訳しています。

sen.cmt: 「貞丈雑記」が、a book on ancient courtly traditions and etiquettes, written by Sadatake Ise in the Edo Period と丁寧に説明されていますが、原文にはありません。念のため。 encountered with → encountered に訂正しました。「笠懸」の注釈中のcompetion はスペルミスのため competition に訂正しました。「鷹すえたる人鵜つかひ」の部分はわかる範囲で訂正しました。

sen.j: 訪問においては、参朝はいうまでもなく、宮門で下乗、下馬をさせ、寺社もまたそれに準じた。
sen.e: To visit the imperial court, needless to say, people had to dismount their horses or alight from their palanquins at Miyamon gate (a court gate), which manner was followed by visitors to shrines and temples.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、城外に「下馬札」を立てて、城中では将軍以外はその身分に応じて下馬の制限を受けた。
sen.e: In the Edo Period, "Geba-fuda" (a bulletin board to notify prohibitiion of entering on a horse) was put up outside of the castle, and every body inside the castle, except Shogun, was restricted in riding a horse depending on their ranks.

In the Edo period, "Geba-fuda" (a sign to notify prohibitiion of entering on a horse) was put up outside of the castle, and inside the castle, everybody except Shogun was restricted in riding a horse depending on their ranks.
sen.cmt: Edo Period → Edo period に変更しました。「下馬札」の後にある注釈の bulletin board は「張り紙をするための掲示板」という感じがするので、sign に置き換えました。 every body → everybody に訂正しました。 "everybody inside the castle" だと、城内にいる（場内で働く・住む）すべての人々という感じがするので、everybody の位置をexcept の前に訂正しました。Shogun の後のコンマは必要ないと考え、削除しました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, a "Geba-fuda" (a sign notifying horse riders that they are prohibited from entering the area indicated while mounted on a horse) was put up outside of a castle, and inside the castle, everybody except the shogun was, depending on their rank, obliged to dismount from their horse.

sen.j: たとえば、親王、大納言以上でも、中門で下乗した。
sen.e: For example, even Imperial Princes and other nobles ranked higher than Dainagon (a major councillor of state) had to get down from their palanquin at Chumon gate (an inner gate in the castle).
For example, even imperial princes and other nobles ranked higher than Dainagon (a major councilor of state) had to get down from their palanquin at Chumon gate (an inner gate in the castle).
sen.cmt: Imperial Princes → imperial princes：複数なので、大文字を小文字に変えました。 スペルミス： councillor → councilor に訂正しました。

sen.j: 幕末、下馬、下乗の廃れたが、明治維新後、明治元年閏4月の下乗下馬の制から始まり、明治12年までに変遷はあるが、宮城、離宮、諸官省、社寺などに一定の制があった。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo Period, this custom of dismounting a horse or getting down from a palanquin had once died out, but after the Meiji Restoration, the same system resumed in leap April, 1868, and lasted to a certain extent until 1879, through some changes, at Kyujo (imperial palaces), Rikyu (imperial villas), various ministries and some temples and shrines.

sen.j: 下乗、下馬には成文があるが、下馬札の成文は見当たらない。
sen.e: The terms of "Gejo" and "Geba" (dismounting a horse and alighting from a palanquin) were described in statutory laws, but there was no statutory law that referred to the term "Geba-fuda" (a bulletin board to instruct Gejo and Geba).
The terms "Gejo" and "Geba" (dismounting a horse and alighting from a palanquin) can be seen in a document, but the term "Geba-fuda" (a sign to instruct Gejo and Geba) was not found.
sen.cmt: terms of → terms： of を削除しました。 広辞苑によると「成文」の意味は「文章に書き表すこと。また、その文章」とされており、「法律」の意味合いはありません。したがって、were described → can be seen, statutory laws → a document としました。
sen.e: The terms "Gejo" and "Geba" (dismounting a horse and alighting from a palanquin) can be seen in a document, but the term "Geba-fuda" (a sign to instruct Gejo and Geba) was not found.

sen.j: その起源は明らかでないが、「大唐西域記」に、釈迦が霊鷲山で説法する時、退凡下乗の卒塔婆を建てたことが見える。
sen.e: The origin of "Geba-fuda" is not known, but it was described in "The Great Tang Dynasty Record of the Western Regions" that, when Shakyamuni (Buddha) was preaching at Ryojusen Mountain, he had put up Sotoba (a tall, narrow wooden tablet) to notify all nobles to get down from their palanquins or dismount their horses and all ordinary people not to enter into the area secured for his preaching.

sen.j: 明治2年8月、神宮、官国幣社に皇族の参拝のある時、下馬下乗の場所を指定するよう教部省から令されている。
sen.e: In August, 1869, Kyobusho (the Ministry of Religion) issued an ordinance for Jingu Shrine and other Kankoku Heisha (a general term for high-ranked shrines under direct control of the central government) to designate places to dismount a horse or to alight from a palanquin in their precincts when Imperial families visit there.
